headline: More House Democrats Back Impeachment Inquiry
summary: The move to impeach President Trump gained momentum as more House Democrats called for an inquiry into reports that he repeatedly pressed Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Send More Migrants to Mexico to Await Asylum Hearings
summary: Nearly all immigrants who apply for asylum as families will be sent to Mexico to wait for their claims to be decided, acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan said Monday.

headline: GM Furloughs More Workers as UAW Strike Continues
summary: A United Auto Workers strike at General Motors is likely headed into its ninth day, a work stoppage that has led to temporary layoffs for more than 3,000 GM employees in the U.S. and Canada who aren’t involved in the walkout.

headline: ‘Rio Treaty’ Nations to Cooperate on Sanctions on Venezuela’s Maduro
summary: Western Hemisphere nations voted Monday to employ a regional treaty to impose sanctions against embattled Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro, accusing his regime of criminal activity including drug trafficking and money laundering.

headline: Two Mortar Blasts Rock U.S. Embassy in Iraq
summary: Two mortars were fired into the Iraqi capital’s center where the U.S. Embassy is located, security officials said, an incident that comes amid heightened tensions in the region after the U.S. blamed Iran for attacks on Saudi Arabia’s oil facilities.

headline: SoFi Pays Clients for Unexpected Tax Hit
summary: Social Finance Inc. is paying money to customers for unexpected capital-gains taxes after the financial technology startup pulled money from Vanguard’s funds into its own ETFs.

summary: World leaders pledged to do more to combat climate change Monday at a United Nations summit, but they were reprimanded by teenage activist Greta Thunberg, who accused them of “empty words.”

headline: Newark Says Water Safe With Filters
summary: Officials said it is safe for Newark, N.J., residents to resume consuming tap water using city-issued filters. Preliminary results show about 97% of tested filters worked properly and reduced lead levels in the tap water.

summary: The allegations of improper conduct were in connection to a total of 19 engagements with 15 unidentified companies over a three-year period ending in 2016.
